t: Nahum 1
An*p oracle concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum of Elkosh.
God’s Wrath Against Nineveh
The*pn Lord*s is a jealous and avenging God; the*ld Lord*s is avenging and wrathful; the*ln Lord*s takes vengeance on his adversaries and*ld keeps wrath for his enemies.
The*ln Lord*s is slow to anger and great in power, and*ld the Lord*s will by no means clear the guilty. His*ln way is in whirlwind and storm, and*ld the clouds are the dust of his feet.
He*ln rebukes the sea and makes it dry; he*ld dries up all the rivers; Bashan*ln and Carmel wither; the*ld bloom of Lebanon withers.
The*ln mountains quake before him; the*ld hills melt; the*ln earth heaves before him, the*ld world and all who dwell in it.
Who*pn can stand before his indignation? Who*ld can endure the heat of his anger? His*ln wrath is poured out like fire, and*ld the rocks are broken into pieces by him.
The*ln Lord*s is good, a*ld stronghold in the day of trouble; he*ln knows those who take refuge in him.
But*ld with an overflowing flood he*ln will make a complete end of the adversaries, and*ld will pursue his enemies into darkness.
What*ln do you plot against the Lord?*s He*ld will make a complete end; trouble*ld will not rise up a second time.
For*ln they are like entangled thorns, like*ld drunkards as they drink; they*ld are consumed like stubble fully dried.
From*ln you came one who*ld plotted evil against the Lord,*s a*ld worthless counselor.
Thus*pn says the Lord,*s “Though*ln they are at full strength and many, they*ld will be cut down and pass away. Though*ln I have afflicted you, I*ld will afflict you no more.
And*ln now I will break his yoke from off you and*ld will burst your bonds apart.”

The*pn Lord*s has given commandment about you: “No*ld more shall your name be perpetuated; from*ln the house of your gods I will cut off the*ld carved image and the metal image. I*ln will make your grave, for you are vile.”

Behold,*pn upon the mountains, the feet of him who*ld brings good news, who*ld publishes peace! Keep*ln your feasts, O Judah; fulfill*ld your vows, for*ln never again shall the worthless pass through you; he*ld is utterly cut off.
Nahum 2
The Destruction of Nineveh
The*pn scatterer has come up against you. Man*ld the ramparts; watch*ld the road; dress*ln for battle; collect*ld all your strength.
For*pn the Lord*s is restoring the majesty of Jacob as*ld the majesty of Israel, for*ln plunderers have plundered them and*ld ruined their branches.
The*pn shield of his mighty men is red; his*ld soldiers are clothed in scarlet. The*ln chariots come with flashing metal on*ld the day he musters them; the*ld cypress spears are brandished.
The*ln chariots race madly through the streets; they*ld rush to and fro through the squares; they*ln gleam like torches; they*ld dart like lightning.
He*ln remembers his officers; they*ld stumble as they go, they*ln hasten to the wall; the*ld siege tower is set up.
The*ln river gates are opened; the*ld palace melts away;
its*ln mistress is stripped; she is carried off, her*ld slave girls lamenting, moaning*ln like doves and*ld beating their breasts.
Nineveh*ln is like a pool whose*ld waters run away. “Halt!*ln Halt!” they cry, but*ld none turns back.
Plunder*ln the silver, plunder*ld the gold! There*ln is no end of the treasure or*ld of the wealth of all precious things.
Desolate!*pn Desolation and ruin! Hearts*ld melt and knees tremble; anguish*ln is in all loins; all*ld faces grow pale!
Where*ln is the lions’ den, the*ld feeding place of the young lions, where*ln the lion and lioness went, where*ld his cubs were, with none to disturb?
The*ln lion tore enough for his cubs and*ld strangled prey for his lionesses; he*ln filled his caves with prey and*ld his dens with torn flesh.

Behold,*p I am against you, declares the Lord*s of hosts, and I will burn your chariots in smoke, and the sword shall devour your young lions. I will cut off your prey from the earth, and the voice of your messengers shall no longer be heard.
Nahum 3
Woe to Nineveh
Woe*pn to the bloody city, all*ld full of lies and plunder— no*ld end to the prey!
The*ln crack of the whip, and rumble of the wheel, galloping*ld horse and bounding chariot!
Horsemen*ln charging, flashing*ld sword and glittering spear, hosts*ln of slain, heaps*ld of corpses, dead*ln bodies without end— they*ld stumble over the bodies!
And*ln all for the countless whorings of the prostitute, graceful*ld and of deadly charms, who*ln betrays nations with her whorings, and*ld peoples with her charms.
Behold,*pn I am against you, declares*ld the Lord*s of hosts, and*ld will lift up your skirts over your face; and*ln I will make nations look at your nakedness and*ld kingdoms at your shame.
I*ln will throw filth at you and*ld treat you with contempt and*ld make you a spectacle.
And*ln all who look at you will shrink from you and say, “Wasted*ln is Nineveh; who will grieve for her?” Where*ld shall I seek comforters for you?
Are*pn you better than Thebes that*ld sat by the Nile, with*ln water around her, her*ld rampart a sea, and*ld water her wall?
Cush*ln was her strength; Egypt*ld too, and that without limit; Put*ld and the Libyans were her helpers.

Yet*pn she became an exile; she*ld went into captivity; her*ln infants were dashed in pieces at*ld the head of every street; for*ln her honored men lots were cast, and*ld all her great men were bound in chains.
You*ln also will be drunken; you*ld will go into hiding; you*ln will seek a refuge from the enemy.
All*ln your fortresses are like fig trees with*ld first-ripe figs— if*ln shaken they fall into*ld the mouth of the eater.
Behold,*ln your troops are*ld women in your midst. The*ln gates of your land are*ld wide open to your enemies; fire*ld has devoured your bars.
Draw*pn water for the siege; strengthen*ld your forts; go*ln into the clay; tread*ld the mortar; take*ld hold of the brick mold!
There*ln will the fire devour you; the*ld sword will cut you off. It*ld will devour you like the locust. Multiply*ln yourselves like the locust; multiply*ld like the grasshopper!
You*ln increased your merchants more*ld than the stars of the heavens. The*ld locust spreads its wings and flies away.
Your*pn princes are like grasshoppers, your*ld scribes like clouds of locusts settling*ln on the fences in*ld a day of cold— when*ln the sun rises, they fly away; no*ld one knows where they are.
Your*pn shepherds are asleep, O*ld king of Assyria; your*ld nobles slumber. Your*ln people are scattered on the mountains with*ld none to gather them.
There*ln is no easing your hurt; your*ld wound is grievous. All*ln who hear the news about you clap*ld their hands over you. For*ln upon whom has not come your*ld unceasing evil?
